titleproper.value:
Guide to the Children's Colonies Photograph Collection
            <num>ALBA.PHOTO.148</num>

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

addressline: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace
        <date>2017-07-19T18:49:31</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

abstract.value:
During the Spanish Civil War
        (1936-1939) Colonias Infantiles (children's colonies) were established in rural locales by
        the government of the Spanish Republic after fascist forces bombed Spanish cities, and many
        thousands of children were orphaned, driven from their homes or made destitute by war.
        Children's colonies were established in Spain, and individuals and groups of child refugees
        were also sent abroad for safety. Spanish children's colonies were founded in France and the
        United Kingdom at this time. The collection contains photographs of children eating,
        bathing, studying, doing chores, resting, and playing.

p.value:
Materials are open to researchers. Please contact the Tamiment Library & Robert F.
        Wagner Labor Archives for more information and to schedule an appointment,
        tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu or 212-998-2630.

Published citations should take the following form: <lb/><lb/>Identification of item, date;
        Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number; <lb/>Tamiment Library/Robert
        F. Wagner Labor Archives <lb/>Elmer Holmes Bobst Library <lb/>70 Washington Square South
        <lb/>New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.

During the Spanish Civil War (1936-1939), roughly 200,000 of the 600,000 refugees seeking
        shelter from the armies of Generalissimo Franco and his fascist allies were children. Many
        children were orphaned or lost their homes. The bombing of large cities placed children at
        greatest risk, and many were moved to safer locations in the rural periphery. The government
        of the Spanish Republic established colonias infantiles (children's colonies), often in
        rural estates which had been abandoned by fascist sympathizers. Some parents and guardians
        sent children, individually or in groups, abroad for safety. Children's colonies were
        established in Spain, as well as in France and the United Kingdom, affording young refugees
        the opportunity to receive an education, medical care, and the company of other Spanish
        children. Photographs of children in these homes or colonies were taken for use in
        periodicals or publicity material, either produced by the Republic or produced and
        distributed by aid organizations in various countries.

<emph render="bold">Series I: The Children's Colonies Photograph Collection</emph>consists
        of photographs related to the children's colonies in Spain and France. A number of the
        prints are stamped to indicate that they were taken for the Propaganda Section of the
        Republic's Children's Aid organization (Ajut Infantil de Reraguarda). The collection
        contains photographs of children eating, bathing, studying, doing chores, resting, and
        playing. Some images show teachers or other adult staff of the colonies. A number of files
        include exterior views of colony buildings, and interior shots of dormitories and dining
        halls. Of the total, 347 black and white prints are in files arranged alphabetically by
        either the name or the location of the colony. In addition to the images of children in
        identified colonies, there are ten images of children with donated toys and nine images of
        children in undesignated locations.
